case_name: Union of India and others v. Ravi Varma, Ganapathi Kini, Suresh Kumar and Tara Chand Jain

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1845 and 1846 of 1968 filed by Union of India and two others by special leave against Mysore High Court judgment dated January 10, 1968 and October 20, 1967 in Writ Petitions Nos. 1519 of 1967 and 1216 of 1965

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1845 and 1846 of 1968. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 10, 1968 and October 20, 1967 of the Mysore High Court in Writ PetitiOns Nos. 1519 of 1067 and 1216 of 1965- respectively.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 50 of 1969 filed by Union of India and two others on certificate from Punjab and Haryana High Court against judgment reversing single judge decision

anchor.surface_text: Similar question arises in respect of the seniority of Suresh Kumar and Tara Chand Jain, respondents in civil appeal No. 50 of 1969 which has been filed by the Union of India and two others on a ,certificate granted by the Punjab and Haryana High Court against the judgment of that Court reversing in Letters Patent appeal the ,decision of the single judge and issuing a writ in favour of those respondents.

facts.text: Ministry of Home Affairs issued Office Memorandum dated June 22, 1949 on fixation of seniority of displaced government servants and temporary employees based on length of service in grade

anchor.surface_text: Before giving the facts of the three cases, it would be pertinent to refer to two Office Memoranda issued by the Ministry of Home Affairs. One of the memoranda is dated June 22, 1949. It was mentioned in this memorandum that the Government of India had under companysideration the question of the fixation of seniority of displaced government servants and temporary employees in the various grades.

facts.text: Ministry of Home Affairs issued Office Memorandum dated December 22, 1959 cancelling earlier instructions and adopting general principles for seniority not applicable retrospectively

anchor.surface_text: On December 22, 1959 another Office Memorandum was issued by the Ministry of Home Affairs on the subject of the general principles for determining seniority of various categories of persons employed in Central services. Material part of this memorandum was as under

facts.text: Ravi Varma appointed as Inspector in Central Excise Collectorate Madras on May 27, 1947 and confirmed on April 7, 1956

anchor.surface_text: Ravi Varma, respondent No. 1 in civil appeal No. 1845 of 1968. was appointed as an Inspector in the Central Excise Collectors in Madras on 27-5-47 and was companyfirmed on 7-4-56.

facts.text: Ganapathi Kini appointed as Inspector in Central Excise Collectorate Madras on May 28, 1947 with service for seniority computed from October 10, 1946 due to war service and confirmed on April 7, 1956

anchor.surface_text: Ganapathi Kini respondent No. 1 in civil appeal No. 1846, was appointed as an inspector in the Central Excise Collectorate in Madras on 28-5-47. In view of the war service rendered by Ganapathi Kini, his service for purposes of seniority was companyputed with effect from 10-10-46 and he was companyfirmed on 7-4-56.

facts.text: In 1959 seniority list of inspectors, Ganapathi Kini at serial No. 115 and Ravi Varma at 141 based on length of service

anchor.surface_text: Ganapathi Kini and Ravi Varma were shown at serial Nos. 115 and 141 in accordance with the length of service in seniority list of inspectors prepared in 1959.

facts.text: Revised seniority list prepared in 1963 per Central Board of Revenue letter dated October 19, 1962 computing from date of confirmation, Ganapathi Kini at 149, Ravi Varma at 150

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently on the directions of the Central Board of Revenue companytained in letter dated October 19, 1962, a revised seniority list was prepared in 1963 by companyputing seniority from the date, of companyifirmation. In the revised list Ganapathi Kini and Ravi Varma were shown at serial, Nos. 149 and 150,

facts.text: Ganapathi Kini and Ravi Varma filed writ petitions under Article 226 for quashing 1963 revised seniority list

anchor.surface_text: Ganapathi Kini and Ravi Varma thereupon filed petitions under article 226 of the Constitution of India praying for quashing the revised seniority list prepared in 1963.

facts.text: Mysore High Court held seniority determined by length of service per 1949 OM, quashed revised list for Ganapathi Kini and Ravi Varma

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges of the Mysore High Court referred to the memoranda dated June 22, 1949 and December 22, 1959 -L736SupCI/72 and held that the altered rule embodied in the Memorandum dated December 22, 1959 for the determination of seniority would be inapplicable to persons appointed before June 22, 1949 like Ganapathi Kini.

facts.text: Suresh Kumar appointed Lower Division Clerk Medical Stores Depot Karnal on October 9, 1950, confirmed March 31, 1960

anchor.surface_text: Suresh Kumar, respondent No. 1 and Tara Chand Jain, res- pondent No 2 in civil appeal No. 50 of 1969 were appointed as Lower Division Clerks in the Medical Stores Depot, Karnal under the Directorate General of High Services on October 9, 1950 and November 26 1951 respectively. Both of them were company firmed on March 31, 1960.

facts.text: Tara Chand Jain appointed Lower Division Clerk Medical Stores Depot Karnal on November 26, 1951, confirmed March 31, 1960

anchor.surface_text: Suresh Kumar, respondent No. 1 and Tara Chand Jain, res- pondent No 2 in civil appeal No. 50 of 1969 were appointed as Lower Division Clerks in the Medical Stores Depot, Karnal under the Directorate General of High Services on October 9, 1950 and November 26 1951 respectively. Both of them were company firmed on March 31, 1960.

facts.text: In seniority list per 1949 OM, Suresh Kumar at serial 32, Tara Chand Jain at 34

anchor.surface_text: In the Seniority list which was Prepared in accordance with Office Memorandum dated June 22, 1949 Suresh Kumar and Tara-Chand Jain, respondents, were shown at serial Nos. 32 and 34 in accordance with their length of Service.

facts.text: Revised seniority list after June 19, 1963 memo showed Suresh Kumar at 40, Tara Chand Jain at 42

anchor.surface_text: A revised seniority list was thereafter prepared and a number of scheduled castes candidates who had been recruited later but had been companyfirmed earlier than Suresh Kumar and Tara Chand Jain were shown senior. Suresh Kumar and Tara Chand Jain were thus shown at serial Nos. 40 and 42 in the revised seniority list

facts.text: Punjab Haryana High Court single judge dismissed writ petitions of Suresh Kumar and Tara Chand Jain, Letters Patent appeal reversed and held governed by 1949 OM

anchor.surface_text: The above petitions were resisted by the appellants and were dismissed by the learned single judge. On Letters Patent appeal the judgment of the single judge was reversed and it was held thatSuresh Kumar and Tara Chand Jain having been appointed prior to December 22, 1959 were Governed by the rule of seniority companytained in the Office Memorandum dated June 22, 1949 issued by the Ministry of Home Affairs.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that 1959 OM not retrospective, seniority of pre-1959 appointees like Ganapathi Kini and Ravi Varma by length of service per 1949 OM

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, manifest that except in certain cases with which we are number companycerned, the Office Memorandum dated December 22, 1959 and the provisions laid down in the Annexure thereto companyld number apply to persons appointed to the various Central services before the date of that Memorandum.

facts.text: Central Board of Revenue letter dated October 19, 1962 directed revised seniority from date of confirmation

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently on the directions of the Central Board of Revenue companytained in letter dated October 19, 1962, a revised seniority list was prepared in 1963 by companyputing seniority from the date, of companyifirmation.

facts.text: Directorate General of Health Services issued Memorandum dated June 19, 1963 referring to 1959 OM revising seniority

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently Memorandum dated June 19, 1963 Was received from the Directorate General of Health Services in which there was a reference to the Ministry of Home Affairs office Memorandum date December 22, 1959.

facts.text: Central Board of Revenue letter dated July 3, 1957 adopted rule of date of confirmation for seniority

anchor.surface_text: Argument was advanced on behalf of the appellants that on July 3, 1957 the Central Board of Revenue had again adopted the rule that the date of the companyfirmation should form the basis for determination of seniority.

facts.text: Suresh Kumar and Tara Chand Jain appointed prior to December 22, 1959 governed by 1949 OM length of service rule

anchor.surface_text: As Suresh Kumar and Tara Chand Jain, respondents, were appointed prior to December 22, 1959 their seniority was governed by the rule of length of service as companytained in Office Memorandum 1004 dated June 22, 1949

anchor.surface_text: On December 22, 1959 another Office Memorandum was issued by the Ministry of Home Affairs on the subject of the general principles for determining seniority of various categories of persons employed in Central services. Material part of this memorandum was as under The instructions contained in this Ministrys Office Memorandum No. 30/44/48-Apptts, dated the 22nd June, 1949, were issued in order to safeguard the interests of displaced Government servants appointed to the Central Services after partition.

concepts.interpretation: Administrative instructions like 1959 OM do not apply retrospectively to appointments made prior to its date; seniority of pre-1959 appointees governed by earlier 1949 OM based on length of service.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ted January 28, 1952, April 20, 1961 and March 27, 1963 issued by the Ministry of Home Affairs to show a departure from the rule of seniority for the

concepts.unlisted_description: Rule that new seniority principles do not disturb existing seniority of prior appointees unless specified.

concepts.interpretation: Authority to issue instructions on recruitment, promotion, and seniority in Central services vests with Ministry of Home Affairs, not subordinate directorates.
concepts.unlisted_label: Government of India Allocation of Business Rules, 1961
concepts.unlisted_description: Rules allocating business among Union ministries, assigning general service matters to Home Affairs.

issues.text: Whether the criterion to determine the seniority of Ravi Varma and Ganapathi Kini respondents should be length of service in accordance with the Office Memorandum dated June 22, 1949 issued by the Ministry of Home Affairs, as claimed by the said respondents, or whether it should be the date of confirmation, as claimed by the appellants

anchor.surface_text: Whether the criterion to determine the seniority of Ravi Varma and Ganapathi Kini respondents should be length of service in accordance with the Office Memorandum dated June 22, 1949 issued by the Ministry of Home Affairs, as claimed by the said respondents, or whether it should be the date of confirmation, as claimed by the appellants

issues.text: Similar question arises in respect of the seniority of Suresh Kumar and Tara Chand Jain, respondents in civil appeal No. 50 of 1969

issues.text: Whether the Office Memorandum dated December 22, 1959 applies with retrospective effect to persons appointed to Central services prior to its date

anchor.surface_text: The Office Memorandum dated December 22, 1959, however, expressly made it clear that the general principles embodied in the Annexure thereto were number to have retrospective, effect. In order to put the matter beyond any Pale of companytroversy, it was mentioned that hereafter the seniority of all persons appointed to the various Central Services after the date of these instructions should be determined in accor dance with the General principles annexed hereto.

issues.text: Whether the Memorandum dated June 19, 1963 issued by the Directorate General of Health Services could validly revise the seniority of pre-1959 appointees and affect their position relative to scheduled caste candidates

anchor.surface_text: It is numberdoubt true that a direction was given in the Memorandum of the Directorate General of Health Services that scheduled caste and scheduled tribe candidates companyfirmed in reserved vacancies should be ranked senior to temporary, including quasi- permanent persons, irrespective of their position in the seniority list, but such a direction went beyond the rule of seniority companytained in the, Office Memorandum dated December 22, 1959 issued by the Ministry of Home Affairs in respect of employees appointed before that date.

holdings.text: The Office Memorandum dated December 22, 1959 and the provisions laid down in the Annexure thereto could not apply to persons appointed to the various Central services before the date of that Memorandum.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, manifest that except in certain cases with which we are number companycerned, the Office Memorandum dated December 22, 1959 and the provisions laid down in the Annexure thereto companyld number apply to persons appointed to the various Central services before the date of that Memorandum.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit non-retrospective language in 1959 OM limits application to post-1959 appointments; prior seniority fixed under earlier rules undisturbed; supported by Mervyn Coutinho precedent.

holdings.text: The seniority of Ganapathi Kini and Ravi Varma, who were appointed prior to December 22, 1959, must be determined on the basis of length of service per Office Memorandum dated June 22, 1949, not date of confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: As the said Office Memorandum has, except in certain cases with which we are number companycerned, applied the rule of seniority contained in the Annexure thereto only to employees appointed after the date of that Memorandum, there is no escape from the conclusion that the seniority of Ganapathi Kini and Ravi Varma, respondents, who were appointed prior to December 22, 1959, would have to be determined on the basis of their length of service in accordance with Office Memorandum dated June 22, 1949 and not on the basis of the date of their confirmation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-1959 appointments governed by 1949 OM length of service rule; 1959 OM non-retro; CBR 1971 letter confirms application only post-1959; supersedes prior CBR instructions.

holdings.text: Seniority of Suresh Kumar and Tara Chand Jain, appointed prior to December 22, 1959, governed by length of service rule in 1949 Office Memorandum, not date of confirmation in 1959 Annexure.

anchor.surface_text: As Suresh Kumar and Tara Chand Jain, respondents, were appointed prior to December 22, 1959 their seniority was governed by the rule of length of service as contained in Office Memorandum dated June 22, 1949 and not by the rule based upon date of confirmation as contained in the Annexure to the Memorandum dated December 22, 1959.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of non-retro 1959 OM principle to pre-1959 health services appointees; 1949 OM controls.

holdings.text: 1963 Directorate General of Health Services Memorandum exceeds 1959 OM for pre-1959 employees and lacks authority under Allocation of Business Rules as seniority matters vest with Ministry of Home Affairs.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direction contradicts non-retro 1959 OM; subordinate directorate cannot override Home Ministry on general seniority rules per Allocation Rules.
